item.title: In Afghan Presidential Campaign, North Is All-Important
item.description: Many of the major candidates have focused in recent weeks on the country’s northern regions, where the most voters turned out in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Supporters of Zalmay Rassoul at a rally in Herat. Mr. Rassoul lacks a natural base and is relying on his running mate, the brother of a northern resistance fighter.

item.title: More Ships and Planes Join Search for Jetliner
item.description: Ten planes and ten ships scoured the latest search area, roughly the size of Poland.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Greece Passes Economic Measures, Clearing the Way for Bailout Money
item.description: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras called the vote, after hours of debate in Parliament and an attempt by the leftist opposition to delay it, “a huge step toward the Greece of tomorrow.”
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Large Crowds Fill Taipei Streets in Protest Over China Trade Bill
item.description: A pact that would drop barriers to trade in services with China has spurred concern in Taiwan, where student-led demonstrators continue to occupy the legislature.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Protesters attending a rally in Taipei to support students who have occupied the legislature for nearly two weeks.

item.title: North Korea Vows to Use ‘New Form’ of Nuclear Test
item.description: The North did not elaborate, but Western analysts have long suspected that it is trying to make nuclear devices that could be delivered by intercontinental ballistic missiles.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Obama Trip Spurs Inquiry of Behavior by a Marine
item.description: Witnesses said the Marine, assigned to security work during President Obama’s recent trip to the Netherlands, was drinking, passing around his badge and sharing details of his job.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

item.title: French Voters Shift to the Right in Mayoral Elections
item.description: The poor showing by the Socialist Party is expected to lead to major changes to the government of François Hollande, including a cabinet reshuffle and a change in prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and LILIA BLAISE
item.media:description: Anne Hidalgo, elected mayor of Paris, one of just a few wins Sunday for the Socialist Party.

item.title: Promises of Diplomacy but No Advances in Ukraine Talks
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry began his meeting in Paris with his Russian counterpart on Sunday to seek a political solution to the standoff over Ukraine, the federalization of the country was likely to be at the core of the discussion.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia before their meeting in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: Melilla Journal: A Borderline Where Women Bear the Weight
item.description: Morocco’s “mule ladies” haul goods into the country from Spain, earning as little as three euros per trip. As hard times push men toward these jobs, the working conditions have become dangerous.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: Not on Ballot, Turkey’s Premier Still Gets Push From Party in Local Elections
item.description: Voters delivered what appeared to be a resounding victory for Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Islamist-rooted party in local elections that took on national importance as a referendum on Mr. Erdogan’s 11 years in power.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Journalists Held by Militants in Syria Reunite With Family
item.description: Javier Espinosa and Ricardo García Vilanova arrived in Madrid a day after Mr. Espinosa called his newspaper to say they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Spanish reporter Javier Espinosa reunited with his son at an airport in Madrid on Sunday.

item.title: Religious Tensions Cloud Myanmar Census
item.description: The nationwide count has been criticized because the government has denied members of a long-persecuted Muslim minority the right to identify themselves as Rohingya.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Panel’s Warning on Climate Risk: Worst Is Yet to Come
item.description: A United Nations report warned that climate change is already having sweeping effects on every continent and is likely to grow substantially worse unless greenhouse emissions are brought under control.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Kadir van Lohuizen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greenland'­s immense ice sheet is melting as a result of climate change.

item.title: Afghan Couple Finally Together, but a Storybook Ending Is Far From Ensured
item.description: A man and a woman from different ethnic groups have eloped and been married, but now they face threats of death and arrest.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fatima Kazimi, head of the Bamian Women’s Ministry, helped protect Zakia. On Saturday, Ms. Kazimi fled, too, in fear of reprisal.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Is Canada Tarring Itself?
item.description: Oil development is changing the country’s political life.
item.dc:creator: By JACQUES LESLIE

item.title: European Lawmakers Prepare to Vote on ‘Net Neutrality’
item.description: The legislation, the focus of intense lobbying from all sides, is meant to ensure equitable Internet access for 500 million Europeans.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Online habits of customers like Chris Herbert of London, and their ability to pay, are the focus of the digital policy legislation.

item.title: Thai Protesters Rally, Reviving Drive Against Leaders
item.description: After a lull, critics of Thailand’s prime minister marched in Bangkok, seeking to force her out.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cuba Moves to Attract More Foreign Investment
item.description: Cuban lawmakers on Saturday replaced a 1995 foreign investment law that has lured less overseas capital than the island’s Communist leaders had hoped.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Few Safe Places for Central African Republic’s Muslims
item.description: About 4,000 are trapped in one of the largest Muslim communities, afraid to leave lest they be harassed by Christian militia fighters.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Same-Sex Couples Marry Under New Law
item.description: Some gay couples in Britain waited decades for the right to get married. When the opportunity came, it took just a few minutes to make history.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Tanya Ward, right, and Nikki Pettit, among the first gay couples to legally marry in Brighton, were showered on Saturday.

item.title: Leo Bretholz, 93, Dies; Escaped Train to Auschwitz
item.description: Mr. Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue the French railway S.N.C.F. for its role in Nazi deportations to death camps.
item.category: S.N.C.F. (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Leo Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue a French railway for its role in death-camp deportations.

item.title: Credibility of Afghan Vote in Doubt as Observers Flee Violence
item.description: Many international election monitors curtailed their activities or made plans to evacuate their foreign employees, potentially raising serious questions about the election’s validity.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan security forces blocked a street leading to election commission offices attacked Saturday.

item.title: As Diplomacy Steps Up, Ukraine Candidates Narrow
item.description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, who will meet with Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday, said the two sides were narrowing their differences.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Remaking a Life, After Years in an Israeli Prison
item.description: Demonized as terrorists by Israelis and lionized as freedom fighters by Palestinians, prisoners like Muqdad Salah have become a flash point in the troubled peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muqdad Salah, who served time for killing an Israeli man, and Kefaya Abu Omar in Nablus in November for their wedding.

item.title: Hardy Divers in Korea Strait, ‘Sea Women’ Are Dwindling
item.description: For ages, the sea women of Jeju, off the southern coast of South Korea, have braved treacherous waters for their harvest.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
